paragraph: CHAPTER 1. "GOOD-BYE" TO THE OLD LIFE.
tokens: good old life

paragraph: "Me want to see Hetty," said an imperious baby voice.
tokens: want see say imperious baby voice

paragraph: "No, no; not this morning, Miss Nan, dear."
tokens: morning dear

paragraph: "Me do want to see Hetty," was the quick, impatient reply.  And a sturdy indignant little face looked up at Nurse, to watch the effect of the last decisive words.
tokens: want see quick impatient reply sturdy indignant little face look watch effect last decisive word

paragraph: Finding no affirmative reply on Nurse's placid face, the small lips closed firmly--two dimples came and went on two very round cheeks--the mischievous brown eyes grew full of laughter, and the next moment the little questioner had squeezed her way through a slightly open door, and was toddling down the broad stone stairs and across a landing to Hetty's room.  The room door was open, so the truant went in.  A bed with the bedclothes all tossed about, a half worn-out slipper on the floor, a very untidy dressing-table met her eyes, but no Hetty.

paragraph: "Me want Hetty, me do," piped the treble voice, and then the little feet commenced a careful and watchful pilgrimage, the lips still firmly shut, the dimples coming and going, and the eyes throwing many upward glances in the direction of Nurse and the nursery.
tokens: want do pipe treble voice little foot commence careful watchful pilgrimage lip shut dimple come go eye throw many upward glance direction nursery

paragraph: No pursuit as yet, and great, great hope of finding Hetty somewhere in the down-stair regions.  Ah, now, how good! those dangerous stairs had been descended, and the little voice calling in shrill tones for Hetty rang out in the wide hall.
tokens: pursuit great great hope find stair region good dangerous stair descend little voice call shrill tone ring wide hall

paragraph: "Let her come to me," suddenly said an answering voice, and a girl of about twelve, dressed in deep mourning, suddenly opened the door of a small study and clasped the little one in her arms.
tokens: let come say answer voice girl dress deep mourn open door small study clasp little one arm

paragraph: "So you have found me, my precious, my dearest!  Brave, plucky little Nan, you have got away from Nurse and found me out!  Come into the study, now, darling, and you shall have some breakfast."
tokens: find precious dearest brave plucky little get find come study darling have breakfast

paragraph: "Me want a bicky, Hetty," said the baby voice; the round arms clasped Hester's neck, but the brown eyes were already travelling eagerly over the breakfast table in quest of spoil for those rosy little lips.
tokens: want bicky say baby voice round arm clasp neck brown eye travel breakfast table quest spoil rosy little lip

paragraph: "Here are two biscuits, Nan.  Nan, look me in the face--here, sit steady on my knee; you lose me, don't you Nan?"
tokens: biscuit nan look face sit steady knee lose

paragraph: "Course me do," said the child.
tokens: course do say child

paragraph: "And I'm going away from you, Nan, darling.  For months and months I won't see anything of you.  My heart will be always with you, and I shall think of you morning, noon, and night.  I love no one as I love you, Nan.  You will think of me, and love me too; won't you, Nan?"
tokens: go month month see heart think morning noon night love love think love

paragraph: "Me will," said Nan; "me want more bicky, Hetty."
tokens: say want bicky

paragraph: "Yes, yes," answered Hester; "put your arms tight round my neck, and you shall have sugar, too.  Tighter than that, Nan, and you shall have two lumps of sugar--oh, yes, you shall--I don't care if it makes you sick-- you shall have just what you want the last moment we are together."
tokens: answer put arm tight neck have sugar tighter have lump sugar care make sick have want last moment

paragraph: Baby Nan was only too pleased to crumple up a crape frill and to smear a black dress with sticky little fingers for the sake of the sugar which Hetty plied her with.
tokens: pleased crumple crape frill smear black dress sticky little finger sake sugar ply

paragraph: "More, Hetty," she said; "me'll skeeze 'oo vedy tight for more."
tokens: more say skeeze tight more

paragraph: On this scene Nurse unexpectedly entered.
tokens: scene enter

paragraph: "Well, I never! and so you found your way all downstairs by yourself, you little toddle.  Now, Miss Hetty, I hope you haven't been giving the precious lamb sugar; you know it never does suit the little dear.  Oh, fie! baby; and what sticky hands!  Miss Hetty, she has crumpled all your crape frills."

paragraph: "What matter?" said Hester.  "I wanted a good hug, and I gave her three or four lumps.  Babies won't squeeze you tight for nothing.  There, my Nancy, go back to Nurse.  Nurse, take her away; I'll break down in a minute if I see her looking at me with that little pout."

paragraph: Nurse took the child into her arms.
tokens: nurse take child arm

paragraph: "Good-bye, Miss Hester, dear.  Try to be a good girl at school.  Take my word, missy--things won't be as dark as they seem."
tokens: good dear try good girl school take word thing dark seem

paragraph: "Good-bye, Nurse," said Hester hastily.  "Is that you, father? are you calling me?"
tokens: good say father call

paragraph: She gathered up her muff and gloves, and ran out of the little study where she had been making believe to eat breakfast.  A tall, stern-looking man was in the hall, buttoning on an overcoat; a brougham waited at the door.  The next moment Hester and her father were bowling away in the direction of the nearest railway station.  Nan's little chubby face had faded from view.  The old square grey house, sacred to Hester because of Nan, had also disappeared; the avenue even was past, and Hester closed her bright brown eyes.  She felt that she was being pushed out into a cold world, and was no longer in the same snug nest with Nan.  An intolerable pain was at her heart; she did not glance at her father, who during their entire drive occupied himself over his morning paper.  At last they reached the railway station, and just as Sir John Thornton was handing his daughter into a comfortable first-class carriage, marked "For Ladies only," and was presenting her with her railway ticket and a copy of the last week's illustrated newspaper, he spoke--
tokens: gather muff glove run little study make believe eat breakfast tall stern look man hall button overcoat brougham wait door next moment father bowl direction near railway station little chubby face fade view old square grey house sacred disappear avenue past close bright brown eye feel push cold world same snug nest intolerable pain heart glance father entire drive occupy morning paper last reach railway station hand daughter comfortable first class carriage mark lady present railway ticket copy last week illustrate newspaper speak

paragraph: "The guard will take care of you, Hester.  I am giving him full directions, and he will come to you at every station, and bring you tea or any refreshment you may require.  This train takes you straight to Sefton, and Mrs Willis will meet you, or send for you there.  Good-bye, my love; try to be a good girl, and curb your wild spirits.  I hope to see you very much improved when you come home at Midsummer.  Good-bye, dear, good-bye.  Ah, you want to kiss me--well, just one kiss.  There-- oh, my dear! you know I have a great dislike to emotion in public."
tokens: guard take care give full direction come station bring tea refreshment require train take meet send good love try good girl curb wild spirit hope see improve come good dear good bye want kiss kiss dear know have great dislike emotion public

paragraph: Sir John Thornton said this because a pair of arms had been flung suddenly round his neck, and two kisses imprinted passionately on his sallow cheek.  A tear also rested on his cheek, but that he wiped away.
tokens: say pair arm flung neck kisse imprint sallow cheek tear rest cheek wipe
